front.title: Hardening DNSSEC against collision weaknesses in SHA-1 and other cryptographic hash algorithms

abstract.t: DNSSEC deployments have often used the SHA-1 cryptographic hash algorithm to provide authentication of DNS data. This document explains why SHA-1 is no longer secure for this purpose, and deprecates its use in DNSSEC signatures. This document updates RFC 8624.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Since 2005, SHA-1 has been known to be much weaker than it was designed to be. Over the last 5 years there has been a series of increasingly powerful demonstrations that SHA-1's weaknesses can be exploited in practice. In January 2020, GaÃ«tan Leurent and Thomas Peyrin announced a chosen-prefix collision for SHA-1 [SHA-mbles]. This was the first practical break of SHA-1 as used in cryptographic signatures.

DNSSEC uses cryptographic signatures to authenticate DNS data. Its signature algorithms include RSASHA1 (5) and RSASHA1-NSEC3-SHA1 (7) which are vulnerable to chosen-prefix collisions in SHA-1, as described in . This document deprecates these vulnerable algorithms ().

SHA-1 has been deprecated in other situations for several years (see ). This document's timetable for deprecating SHA-1 in DNSSEC () is based on those examples, adapted for the particulars of the DNS. discusses the trade-offs between speed and security.

A collision attack can be used against DNSSEC in a number of ways, some of which are explored in . Certain weaknesses in the way DNSSEC is sometimes deployed can make collision attacks easier to carry out, or make their consequences more severe. Although the only sure way to protect against collision attacks is to use a secure algorithm (), and outline some partial mitigations.
The DNS uses SHA-1 for a number of other less vulnerable purposes, as outlined in section .

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words MUST, MUST NOT, REQUIRED, SHALL, SHALL NOT, SHOULD, SHOULD NOT, RECOMMENDED, MAY, and OPTIONAL in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Deprecating SHA-1 in DNSSEC
section.t: The following table lists the implementation recommendations for DNSKEY algorithms . The change from section 3.1 is to deprecate algorithms 5 and 7.
The following subsections have recommended timelines for deprecating algorithms 5 and 7 in specific situations.

section.title: DNSSEC signing software
section.t: DNSSEC key management and zone signing software MUST remove support for algorithms 5 and 7 in their next feature release.

section.title: DNS hosting services
section.t: Authoritative DNS hosting services that include DNSSEC signing as part of the service SHOULD NOT generate a new key with algorithms 5 or 7 for a zone that does not already have a key with the same algorithm. They MUST NOT do so after the end of 2020.
Zones signed with algorithms 5 or 7 SHOULD be rolled over to a mandatory or recommended algorithm as soon as possible. The rollovers MUST be complete before the end of 2021.

section.title: DNSSEC validating software
section.t: Validating resolvers SHOULD have a build-time or run-time option to disable selected DNSKEY algorithms, that is, to treat them as unknown or insecure.
Algorithms 5 and 7 MUST be disabled in 2022 at the latest. If SHA-1 becomes significantly weaker before then, Algorithms 5 and 7 MUST be disabled in a security patch release.

section.title: DNS resolver services
section.t: Validating resolvers MUST treat algorithms 5 and 7 as unknown or insecure after the start of 2022, or earlier if SHA-1 becomes significantly weaker before then.

section.title: Collision attacks and other DNS record types
Other uses of SHA-1 in the DNS
DS and CDS records
section.t: A DS or CDS record securely identifies a DNSKEY record using a cryptographic digest ( section 5). One of the digest types is SHA-1. It is deprecated by .
For this purpose, the digest needs preimage security, which SHA-1 still has, and collision attacks do not affect it.

section.title: NSEC3 records
section.t: NSEC3 is an alternative mechanism for authenticated denial of existence in DNSSEC. It is based on SHA-1 hashes of domain names. The NSEC3 specification discusses collisions in some detail.

NSEC3 can be attacked with an identical-prefix collision, which is simpler than the chosen-prefix collisions that are the main subject of this document. The best collision known at the time of writing uses two SHA-1 input blocks (128 bytes) so a collision could in principle be made to fit into a domain name for an attack on NSEC3. However it will be difficult to make the colliding domain names conform to host name syntax, and the attack will be futile because the signer can defeat it by changing its NSEC3 salt ( section C.2.1).

section.title: SSHFP records
section.t: An SSHFP record securely identifies an SSH server public key using a cryptographic digest . Although SSHFP SHA-1 digests have not yet been deprecated, SHA-256 is preferred .
For SSHFP records the digest needs preimage security, which SHA-1 still has, and collision attacks do not affect it.

section.title: TSIG authentication
section.t: TSIG is a DNS extension for secret-key transaction authentication . Its hmac-sha1 algorithm is deprecated. Collision attacks do not affect HMAC SHA-1.

section.title: Security considerations
section.t: We find ourselves in an awkward and embarrassing situation. As shows, there has been plenty of warning about the weakness of SHA-1. Other parts of the industry started making efforts to deprecate it years ago. But DNSSEC has been complacent.

At the time of writing, there are 1516 top-level domains, of which 1102 use secure DNSSEC algorithms, 274 use algorithms 5 or 7 (RSA SHA-1), and 140 are insecure. In the reverse DNS, 3 RIRs use secure DNSSEC algorithms, 2 RIRs use algorithm 5, and many of the non-RIR legacy delegations are insecure.

section.title: Staying secure
section.t: There are still many domains that depend on SHA-1 to secure applications that use DNSSEC, such as issuing TLS certificates , sending inter-domain email , and authenticating SSH servers .

Some applications use the "authenticated data" (AD bit) signal from DNSSEC to make security decisions, and will fail if it unexpectedly switches off. Other applications use DNSSEC passively and will silently go insecure. In either case we would prefer them to continue working as if secure, as long as SHA-1 is still significantly better than insecure DNS.

section.title: When to declare SHA-1 insecure
section.t: At the time of writing, a SHA-1 chosen-prefix collision costs less than US$100,000 in computer time, takes about a month, and requires the attention of expert cryptanalysts. Attacks seem to be getting better by a factor of 3 or 4 per year.
There is not much time before collisions become affordable, and possible for non-experts to calculate. hopes this will not happen within the next 2 years.

This 2 year guess is likely to be too optimistic, so DNSSEC validators need to be prepared to disable support for SHA-1 by configuration change or security patch as soon as a significantly improved attack on SHA-1 is announced.

section.title: Avoiding unwanted insecurity
section.t: The reason for not deprecating SHA-1 immediately is to allow time to perform algorithm rollovers, so that zones will continue to be secure.
Abruptly forcing SHA-1 zones to be treated as insecure may encourage their operators to leave them insecure, instead of encouraging them to upgrade to a secure algorithm.

section.title: IANA considerations
section.t: This document has no IANA actions.
